Teamwork.title: Build for Real Team Work
Teamwork.content: Make collaboration natural and easy, help teams share knowledge automatically, reduce meetings and emails through better tools, make it easy to help each other without interrupting work - like good group project tools.

Teamwork.title: Prevent Knowledge Silos
Teamwork.content: Automatically identify who knows what, suggest when to share important information, help teams learn from each other's successes, make expertise easy to find when needed - like knowing which friend to ask for help with different subjects.

Teamwork.title: Reduce Frustration Daily
Teamwork.content: Fix the small annoyances that add up, automate boring repetitive tasks, make hard things easier, celebrate small wins and progress - like making daily chores less annoying.

Teamwork.title: Build Confidence, Not Fear
Teamwork.content: Make deployments feel safe and controlled, provide safety nets for mistakes, show progress and improvements clearly, help people learn without embarrassment - like training wheels on a bike.

Teamwork.title: Learn and Adapt Constantly
Teamwork.content: Watch how people actually use the product, learn from what works and what doesn't, make the product smarter over time, adapt to different team styles and needs - like a teacher who adjusts to how students learn best.

Teamwork.title: Measure What Matters
Teamwork.content: Track real improvements, not just activity, measure time saved and stress reduced, watch for positive behavior changes, count problems prevented, not just fixed - like measuring learning, not just time spent studying.

Teamwork.title: Catch Issues Early
Teamwork.content: Find problems when they're small and easy to fix, warn about potential issues before they happen, suggest simple fixes for common mistakes, prevent small issues from becoming big problems - like fixing a small leak before it becomes a flood.

Teamwork.title: Build Safety Into Everything
Teamwork.content: Always have an "undo" button, make dangerous actions hard to do accidentally, provide multiple ways to recover from mistakes, test changes safely before applying them - like safety features in cars.

Teamwork.title: Automate Wisely
Teamwork.content: Only automate things that are boring or error-prone, always let people review and approve important changes, make automation helpful, not annoying, explain what the automation is doing and why - like a helpful robot assistant.

üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.title: Do Exactly What's Asked
üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.content: If your friend asks you to make a peanut butter sandwich, don't add jelly unless they ask for it. Follow instructions exactly without adding your own ideas.

üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.title: Only Use Information You're Given
üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.content: If you're baking cookies and the recipe doesn't say how much sugar to use, stop and ask. Don't guess or make up an amount.

üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.title: Protect People's Privacy
üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.content: Treat everyone's personal information like a secret diary. Don't look at it, don't share it, and definitely don't write it down where others can see it.

üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.title: Use Settings Files, Not Hardcoded Numbers
üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.content: Instead of writing "use 10 apples" in your recipe, write "use [number] apples" and keep the number 10 in a separate note. This way you can easily change to 12 apples later.

üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.title: Keep Good Records
üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.content: Like keeping a science lab notebook - write down what you did, when you did it, and what happened. Use the format your teacher asks for, and don't add extra stuff they didn't request.

üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.title: Never Break Things During Updates
üéØ BASIC WORK RULES.content: When updating a video game, you should still be able to play while it updates. If the update causes problems, you can instantly switch back to the old version.

üèóÔ∏è SYSTEM DESIGN RULES.title: Make All 18 Modules Look the Same
üèóÔ∏è SYSTEM DESIGN RULES.content: All 18 tools should use the same buttons, menus, and look. Like different rooms in the same house - they have the same light switches and door handles.

üèóÔ∏è SYSTEM DESIGN RULES.title: Don't Make People Configure Before Using
üèóÔ∏è SYSTEM DESIGN RULES.content: Things should work right out of the box. Like a new video game - you can start playing immediately, and only set up complex controls later if you want.

üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.title: Solve Real Developer Problems
üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.content: Every feature must fix a real frustration developers face, like making homework easier by having better tools.

üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.title: Prevent Problems Before They Happen
üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.content: Stop issues before they become big problems, like fixing a small leak before it floods the house.

üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.title: Be Extra Careful with Private Data
Don't Make People Think Too Hard
üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.content: Fix common issues with one click, give suggestions without interrupting, automate boring tasks, teach as you go - like having a helpful friend.

üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.title: MMM Engine - Change Behavior
üéØ PROBLEM-SOLVING RULES.content: Help people stop making the same mistakes, increase use of best practices, reduce need for manual fixes, help people solve problems themselves - like a good habit coach.

üîß PLATFORM RULES.title: Process Data Quickly
üîß PLATFORM RULES.content: Handle urgent data in less than 1 second (like answering important texts immediately), group less important data (like checking regular mail once a day), check data quality as it comes in.

üîß PLATFORM RULES.title: Help Without Interrupting
üîß PLATFORM RULES.content: Give help when needed, not before (like waiting to be asked), match help to how complex the task is (like simple vs complex instructions), let experts turn off basic help.

üîß PLATFORM RULES.title: Handle Emergencies Well
üîß PLATFORM RULES.content: Make the right action obvious (like big red stop button), provide one-click solutions, offer multiple ways to recover, show clear progress updates - like good emergency instructions.

üîß PLATFORM RULES.title: Make Developers Happier
üîß PLATFORM RULES.content: Reduce time spent switching between tasks, cut down on boring repetitive work, increase time spent on meaningful coding, build confidence in deployments - like making schoolwork more enjoyable.

## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.title: Write Clean, Readable Code
## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.content: Make code easy to understand and modify, use clear names and simple structures, document why decisions were made, keep code organized and consistent - like writing clear, neat notes.

## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.title: PR Template Block ‚Äî Code Review (paste into `.github/pull_request_template.md`)
Review AI Code Thoroughly
## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.content: All AI-generated TypeScript must be reviewed by humans. Verify types, error handling, and security match our standards.

## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.title: Monitor Bundle Impact
## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.content: Use path imports for large libraries. Avoid barrel imports in hot paths. Set bundle size budgets and monitor them.

## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.title: Quality Dependencies
## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.content: Prefer packages with built-in TypeScript definitions. Use `@types/` packages from DefinitelyTyped. Audit dependencies for type safety.

## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.title: Test Type Boundaries
## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.content: Write tests that verify type narrowing works. Test error cases to ensure proper typing. Use `@ts-expect-error` for expected type failures.

## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.title: Gradual Migration Strategy
## AI & CODE GENERATION RULES.content: When converting JavaScript to TypeScript, use `// @ts-check` in JS files first. Add JSDoc types before conversion. Convert one module at a time.

## Basic Work Rules.title: Prevent First
## Basic Work Rules.content: Validate inputs early (required, type, range, size). Prevention beats cure.

## Basic Work Rules.title: Small, Stable Error Codes
## Basic Work Rules.content: Adopt ~10‚Äì12 canonical codes with severity levels:

## Basic Work Rules.title: Wrap & Chain
## Basic Work Rules.content: When a low-level error occurs, wrap it into your code with a friendly message and keep the original as the cause. Never throw raw framework/driver errors at the edges.

## Basic Work Rules.title: Central Handler at Boundaries
## Basic Work Rules.content: Have one handler per surface (API endpoint, CLI entry, IDE command) that:

## Basic Work Rules.title: Friendly to Users, Detailed in Logs
## Basic Work Rules.content: Users see short, calm guidance. Logs contain context and the cause chain. Never leak secrets.

## Basic Work Rules.title: No Silent Catches
## Basic Work Rules.content: Never swallow errors. If you catch it, either fix, retry (if safe), or wrap & bubble to the central handler.

## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.title: Timeouts Everywhere
## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.content: All I/O (network, file, DB, subprocess) must have a timeout (configurable). No infinite waits.

## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.title: Limited Retries with Backoff
## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.content: Retry only idempotent operations. Max 2‚Äì3 tries. Use exponential backoff + small jitter.

## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.title: Do Not Retry Non-Retriables
## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.content: No retries for validation errors, 401/403, 404, or business rule failures. Surface the issue; guide the user.

## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.title: Idempotency
## Timeouts, Retries, Idempotency.content: Design writes so they are safe to retry (keys/tokens/conflict handling). Document this in your service contract.

## Mapping, Messaging, and UX.title: HTTP/Exit Mapping
## Mapping, Messaging, and UX.content: Map canonical codes to standard outcomes (e.g., 400/401/403/404/409/422/429/5xx). No "200 with error body".

## Mapping, Messaging, and UX.title: Message Catalog
## Mapping, Messaging, and UX.content: Keep a single catalog that maps each code ‚Üí one friendly, human sentence. Translate here, not in code.

## Mapping, Messaging, and UX.title: UI/IDE Behavior
## Mapping, Messaging, and UX.content: Keep UI responsive. Show short, actionable options: Retry / Cancel / Open Logs. No stack traces to users.

## Logging, Observability, and Safety.title: Structured Logs
## Logging, Observability, and Safety.content: One JSON object per line. Include: timestamp, level, service, operation, error.code, trace/request ids, duration, attempt, retryable flag, severity, and a cause chain summary.

## Logging, Observability, and Safety.title: Correlation
## Logging, Observability, and Safety.content: Propagate trace/request ids across calls. Log exactly one request.start and one request.end per request.

## Logging, Observability, and Safety.title: Privacy & Secrets
## Logging, Observability, and Safety.content: Never log secrets or PII. Redact tokens, passwords, cookies, Authorization headers, and sensitive payloads. Log sizes/hashes, not raw bodies.

## Quality, Tests, and Governance.title: Contracts & Docs
## Quality, Tests, and Governance.content: Document the error envelope, code list, HTTP mapping, and examples. Keep examples up to date and non-PII.

## Quality, Tests, and Governance.title: Consistency Over Cleverness
## Quality, Tests, and Governance.content: Prefer consistent handling over one-off fixes. If a new case appears, map it to an existing code first.

## Quality, Tests, and Governance.title: Safe Defaults
## Quality, Tests, and Governance.content: Default timeouts, retry caps, and user messages must be safe and configurable. No hidden magic numbers.

## AI-Specific Error Handling.title: AI Sandbox Safety
## AI-Specific Error Handling.content: AI should only work in a special "playground" (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

## AI-Specific Error Handling.title: AI Learning from Mistakes
## AI-Specific Error Handling.content: When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like learning from test questions.

## AI-Specific Error Handling.title: AI Confidence Thresholds
## AI-Specific Error Handling.content: - High confidence (>90%): Apply automatically with user notification

## System Integration & Recovery.title: Graceful Degradation
## System Integration & Recovery.content: When dependencies fail, provide reduced functionality rather than complete failure. Show clear status of what's working vs. limited.

## System Integration & Recovery.title: State Recovery
## System Integration & Recovery.content: After crashes or failures, systems should recover to known good states. Maintain recovery checkpoints for long-running operations.

## System Integration & Recovery.title: Feature Flag Safety
## System Integration & Recovery.content: Use feature flags for risky changes with automatic rollback on error detection. Monitor error rates by flag state.

## BASIC WORK RULES.title: Strict Mode Always
## BASIC WORK RULES.content: Turn on strict checks everywhere. (Meaning: the compiler catches more mistakes early.)

## BASIC WORK RULES.title: Handle `null`/`undefined`
## BASIC WORK RULES.content: Use optional fields only when needed, and

## BASIC WORK RULES.title: Small, Clear Functions
## BASIC WORK RULES.content: Short functions, clear names. One job per function.

## BASIC WORK RULES.title: Let the Compiler Infer
## BASIC WORK RULES.content: Don't add types the compiler already knows. (Meaning: avoid noisy annotations.)

## BASIC WORK RULES.title: Keep Imports Clean
## BASIC WORK RULES.content: No unused imports. Group by built-in, third-party, then local.

### Self‚ÄëCheck (Author).content: Code should read like a story, not a puzzle.

## TYPE SYSTEM RULES.content: Make simple named types for real data (User, Order). Reuse them.

## TYPE SYSTEM RULES.content: Prefer readonly arrays/props for values that should not change.

## TYPE SYSTEM RULES.content: When you have variants, add a simple

## TYPE SYSTEM RULES.title: Generics, But Simple
## TYPE SYSTEM RULES.content: Use generics when it truly makes code reusable. Keep names short and clear.

## ASYNC, ERRORS, AND SAFETY.title: No Unhandled Promises
## ASYNC, ERRORS, AND SAFETY.content: Always `await` or handle `.catch`. Never let a promise fail silently.

## ASYNC, ERRORS, AND SAFETY.title: Timeouts & Cancel
## ASYNC, ERRORS, AND SAFETY.content: Use timeouts for network/work that may hang. Support

## ASYNC, ERRORS, AND SAFETY.content: Catch errors at boundaries (commands, routes) and show

## PROJECT STRUCTURE & BUILD.title: One Source of Truth
## PROJECT STRUCTURE & BUILD.content: Keep types for APIs in one place (e.g., generated from contracts). Don't hand-roll duplicates.

## PROJECT STRUCTURE & BUILD.title: Paths & Aliases
## PROJECT STRUCTURE & BUILD.content: Use path aliases in config (short imports), but

## PROJECT STRUCTURE & BUILD.title: Modern Output Targets
## PROJECT STRUCTURE & BUILD.content: Target modern JS (ES2022+) for optimal tree-shaking. Keep configs in repo. Builds must be reproducible.

## QUALITY GATES (MUST PASS).title: Lint & Format
## QUALITY GATES (MUST PASS).content: Use eslint + prettier. No warnings in CI.

## QUALITY GATES (MUST PASS).title: Type Check in CI
## QUALITY GATES (MUST PASS).content: Run the compiler (`tsc`) with strict settings on every PR.

## QUALITY GATES (MUST PASS).title: Tests for New Behavior
## QUALITY GATES (MUST PASS).content: Add tests for new logic and for error paths (timeouts, bad input). Keep tests fast.

## SECURITY, PRIVACY, PERFORMANCE.title: Validate Untrusted Inputs at Runtime
## SECURITY, PRIVACY, PERFORMANCE.content: Types help at build time only. Validate external data before use.

## SECURITY, PRIVACY, PERFORMANCE.title: Keep the UI Responsive
## SECURITY, PRIVACY, PERFORMANCE.content: Do heavy work off the main thread. Show progress for long tasks.

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: Name Casing & Charset (Kebab-Case Only)
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: All folder names must use kebab-case: only lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens [a-z0-9-]. No uppercase, no underscores, no spaces. This ensures consistency and avoids path resolution issues across platforms.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: No Source Code/PII in Stores
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: Storage must never contain source code or personally identifiable information (PII). Use handles, IDs, and metadata only. Receipts and evidence stores are for facts about work, not the work itself.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: No Secrets/Private Keys on Disk
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: Never store secrets, passwords, API keys, or private keys on disk. Use secrets manager, HSM, or KMS. Only public keys may be stored in `trust/pubkeys/`. Load sensitive configuration from environment variables or secure vaults.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: JSONL Receipts (Newline-Delimited, Signed, Append-Only)
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: Receipts are the legal truth. Format: newline-delimited JSON (JSONL), one record per line. Each line must be signed over canonical JSON. Receipts are append-only‚Äînever modify or delete existing entries. Invalid lines go to quarantine (laptop) or DLQ (cloud).
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: Time Partitions Use UTC (dt=YYYY-MM-DD)
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: All time-based partitions must use UTC format: `dt=YYYY-MM-DD` (zero-padded). Example: `dt=2025-10-20`. Never use local time, YYYYMMDD format, or MM-DD-YYYY. Optional hot sharding: `dt=.../shard={00..ff}/`.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: Policy Snapshots Must Be Signed
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: All policy snapshots and templates must be signed. Laptops cache policies; authoritative publishing happens in the Product plane. Policy files are JSON and signed for integrity verification.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: Dual Storage Compliance (JSONL Authority, DB Mirrors)
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: JSONL is the authority. Databases (SQLite/Postgres) mirror data for read/query performance, storing raw JSON verbatim with minimal indexes. The database is a read/index plane only. Always write to JSONL first, then mirror to DB.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: Path Resolution via ZU_ROOT Environment Variable
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: All storage paths must be resolved via `ZU_ROOT` environment variable or `config/paths.json`. Never hardcode absolute paths like `D:\ZeroUI` or `/home/user/zeroui`. Enables portable, configurable deployments.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.title: Receipts Validation (Signed, Append-Only, No Code/PII)
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.content: When reading receipts, always verify signatures. Receipts must never contain source code or PII‚Äîonly handles, IDs, and metadata. Enforce append-only semantics: use file mode "a", never "w"; never truncate or seek.
üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governanc.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

## Basic Readability Rules.content: Use descriptive, everyday words instead of technical jargon or abbreviations.

## Basic Readability Rules.content: No nested ternary operators, complex one-liners, or clever tricks.

all_rules.title: Do Exactly What's Asked
all_rules.content: If your friend asks you to make a peanut butter sandwich, don't add jelly unless they ask for it. Follow instructions exactly without adding your own ideas.

all_rules.title: Only Use Information You're Given
all_rules.content: If you're baking cookies and the recipe doesn't say how much sugar to use, stop and ask. Don't guess or make up an amount.

all_rules.title: Protect People's Privacy
all_rules.content: Treat everyone's personal information like a secret diary. Don't look at it, don't share it, and definitely don't write it down where others can see it.

all_rules.title: Use Settings Files, Not Hardcoded Numbers
all_rules.content: Instead of writing "use 10 apples" in your recipe, write "use [number] apples" and keep the number 10 in a separate note. This way you can easily change to 12 apples later.

all_rules.title: Keep Good Records
all_rules.content: Like keeping a science lab notebook - write down what you did, when you did it, and what happened. Use the format your teacher asks for, and don't add extra stuff they didn't request.

all_rules.title: Never Break Things During Updates
all_rules.content: When updating a video game, you should still be able to play while it updates. If the update causes problems, you can instantly switch back to the old version.

all_rules.title: Be Honest About AI Decisions
all_rules.content: When AI suggests something, it should say:

all_rules.title: Check Your Data
all_rules.content: Make sure the AI's training data is like a fair test - balanced questions, up-to-date information, and correct answers.

all_rules.title: Keep AI Safe
all_rules.content: AI should only work in a special "playground" (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

all_rules.title: Learn from Mistakes
all_rules.content: When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like you learn from getting test questions wrong.

all_rules.title: Test Everything
all_rules.content: Always try things out before saying they work. Don't break things that already work. Test both simple cases and tricky situations.

all_rules.title: Write Good Instructions
all_rules.content: Give people working examples they can try themselves, clear explanations of how to use things, and troubleshooting guides for when things go wrong.

all_rules.title: Keep Good Logs
all_rules.content: Write clear notes that are easy to read, use special tracking numbers to follow requests through the system, and measure both technical numbers and business results.

all_rules.title: Make Changes Easy to Undo
all_rules.content: Prefer adding new features rather than changing old ones. Use on/off switches for features. Write down how to go back if something doesn't work.

all_rules.title: Make Things Repeatable
all_rules.content: Write down exactly what ingredients (versions) you used. Don't depend on special kitchen equipment (computer setups). Include simple steps so others can recreate your work.

all_rules.title: Keep Different Parts Separate
all_rules.content: The display screen (user interface) only shows information. The thinking part (business logic) only does calculations. Never mix these two jobs.

all_rules.title: Be Fair to Everyone
all_rules.content: Use clear, simple language everyone can understand. Don't use tricky designs that might confuse people. Make sure people with disabilities can use everything.

all_rules.title: Use the Hybrid System Design
all_rules.content: Our system has four parts:

all_rules.title: Make All 18 Modules Look the Same
all_rules.content: All 18 tools should use the same buttons, menus, and look. Like different rooms in the same house - they have the same light switches and door handles.

all_rules.title: Don't Make People Configure Before Using
all_rules.content: Things should work right out of the box. Like a new video game - you can start playing immediately, and only set up complex controls later if you want.

all_rules.title: Work Without Internet
all_rules.content: Core features must work offline, like being able to write in a notebook when you don't have WiFi. Save actions and sync when you're back online.

all_rules.title: Register Modules the Same Way
all_rules.content: All 18 modules should sign up using the same process, like every student using the same enrollment form.

all_rules.title: Make All Modules Feel Like One Product
all_rules.content: Use the same command names everywhere, make status indicators look the same, handle errors the same way - like different apps made by the same company.

all_rules.title: Solve Real Developer Problems
all_rules.content: Every feature must fix a real frustration developers face, like making homework easier by having better tools.

all_rules.title: Prevent Problems Before They Happen
all_rules.content: Stop issues before they become big problems, like fixing a small leak before it floods the house.

all_rules.title: Be Extra Careful with Private Data
Don't Make People Think Too Hard
all_rules.content: Fix common issues with one click, give suggestions without interrupting, automate boring tasks, teach as you go - like having a helpful friend.

all_rules.title: MMM Engine - Change Behavior
all_rules.content: Help people stop making the same mistakes, increase use of best practices, reduce need for manual fixes, help people solve problems themselves - like a good habit coach.

all_rules.title: Risk Modules - Safety First
all_rules.content: Never make situations worse, always provide undo options, support gradual improvements, verify before big changes - like safety rules in science lab.

all_rules.title: Success Dashboards - Show Business Value
all_rules.content: Connect engineering work to company results, show money saved and time gained, track both current and future benefits - like showing how studying leads to better grades.

all_rules.title: Use All Platform Features
all_rules.content: Use all our built-in tools:

all_rules.title: Process Data Quickly
all_rules.content: Handle urgent data in less than 1 second (like answering important texts immediately), group less important data (like checking regular mail once a day), check data quality as it comes in.

all_rules.title: Help Without Interrupting
all_rules.content: Give help when needed, not before (like waiting to be asked), match help to how complex the task is (like simple vs complex instructions), let experts turn off basic help.

all_rules.title: Handle Emergencies Well
all_rules.content: Make the right action obvious (like big red stop button), provide one-click solutions, offer multiple ways to recover, show clear progress updates - like good emergency instructions.

all_rules.title: Make Developers Happier
all_rules.content: Reduce time spent switching between tasks, cut down on boring repetitive work, increase time spent on meaningful coding, build confidence in deployments - like making schoolwork more enjoyable.

all_rules.title: Track Problems You Prevent
all_rules.content: Count security issues caught early, track deployment failures avoided, measure knowledge gaps found and fixed, watch technical debt prevented - like counting accidents that didn't happen because of safety measures.

all_rules.title: Build Compliance into Workflow
all_rules.content: Check rules automatically during development, monitor compliance in real-time, generate audit reports easily, assess impact of rule changes - like having built-in spell check while writing.

all_rules.title: Security Should Help, Not Block
all_rules.content: Security tips shouldn't break concentration, automate common security fixes, explain security rules in simple terms, prioritize security risks by importance - like friendly security guards rather than prison guards.

all_rules.title: Support Gradual Adoption
all_rules.content: Let teams start with 3-5 most useful modules, each module should work well on its own, show clear paths to add more modules, provide value at every step - like learning math starting with addition, then multiplication.

all_rules.title: Scale from Small to Huge
all_rules.content: Work for 1 developer or 10,000, handle 100 events per day or 10 million, support simple systems and complex ones, meet basic needs and strict regulations - like a playground that works for both small kids and professional athletes.

all_rules.title: Build for Real Team Work
all_rules.content: Make collaboration natural and easy, help teams share knowledge automatically, reduce meetings and emails through better tools, make it easy to help each other without interrupting work - like good group project tools.

all_rules.title: Prevent Knowledge Silos
all_rules.content: Automatically identify who knows what, suggest when to share important information, help teams learn from each other's successes, make expertise easy to find when needed - like knowing which friend to ask for help with different subjects.

all_rules.title: Reduce Frustration Daily
all_rules.content: Fix the small annoyances that add up, automate boring repetitive tasks, make hard things easier, celebrate small wins and progress - like making daily chores less annoying.

all_rules.title: Build Confidence, Not Fear
all_rules.content: Make deployments feel safe and controlled, provide safety nets for mistakes, show progress and improvements clearly, help people learn without embarrassment - like training wheels on a bike.

all_rules.title: Learn and Adapt Constantly
all_rules.content: Watch how people actually use the product, learn from what works and what doesn't, make the product smarter over time, adapt to different team styles and needs - like a teacher who adjusts to how students learn best.

all_rules.title: Measure What Matters
all_rules.content: Track real improvements, not just activity, measure time saved and stress reduced, watch for positive behavior changes, count problems prevented, not just fixed - like measuring learning, not just time spent studying.

all_rules.title: Catch Issues Early
all_rules.content: Find problems when they're small and easy to fix, warn about potential issues before they happen, suggest simple fixes for common mistakes, prevent small issues from becoming big problems - like fixing a small leak before it becomes a flood.

all_rules.title: Build Safety Into Everything
all_rules.content: Always have an "undo" button, make dangerous actions hard to do accidentally, provide multiple ways to recover from mistakes, test changes safely before applying them - like safety features in cars.

all_rules.title: Automate Wisely
all_rules.content: Only automate things that are boring or error-prone, always let people review and approve important changes, make automation helpful, not annoying, explain what the automation is doing and why - like a helpful robot assistant.

all_rules.title: Learn from Experts
all_rules.content: Watch how the best developers work, copy their successful patterns, help everyone work like the experts, share best practices across the whole team - like learning sports from professional athletes.

all_rules.title: Show the Right Information at the Right Time
all_rules.content: Don't overwhelm people with too much information, show what's important right now, hide complexity until it's needed, make status and progress clear at a glance - like a good car dashboard.

all_rules.title: Make Dependencies Visible
all_rules.content: Show how different pieces connect and depend on each other, warn when changes might affect other people, help teams coordinate without meetings, make the system's architecture easy to understand - like a map showing how roads connect.

all_rules.title: Be Predictable and Consistent
all_rules.content: Work the same way every time, don't surprise people with unexpected behavior, explain clearly what will happen before it happens, build trust through reliability - like a reliable friend.

all_rules.title: Never Lose People's Work
all_rules.content: Save work automatically and frequently, provide clear recovery options, back up important information, warn before doing anything that can't be undone - like automatic save in video games.

all_rules.title: Make it Beautiful and Pleasant
all_rules.content: Use clean, attractive designs, choose pleasant colors and fonts, make interactions smooth and satisfying, create an experience people enjoy using - like a well-designed park.

all_rules.title: Respect People's Time
all_rules.content: Load quickly and respond instantly, don't make people wait unnecessarily, streamline common tasks, value every second of people's time - like express checkout lines.

all_rules.title: Write Clean, Readable Code
all_rules.content: Make code easy to understand and modify, use clear names and simple structures, document why decisions were made, keep code organized and consistent - like writing clear, neat notes.

all_rules.title: Handle Edge Cases Gracefully
all_rules.content: Plan for things going wrong, handle errors without crashing, provide helpful error messages, recover smoothly from problems - like having a plan B when things don't go as expected.

all_rules.title: Encourage Better Ways of Working
all_rules.content: Suggest improvements to processes, help teams adopt better practices, make good habits easy to form, reward continuous improvement - like a good coach.

all_rules.title: Adapt to Different Skill Levels
all_rules.content: Help beginners learn quickly, support experts with advanced features, don't force one way of working on everyone, grow with people as they learn and improve - like books with different reading levels.

all_rules.title: Be Helpful, Not Annoying
all_rules.content: Offer help when it's actually needed, know when to be quiet and stay out of the way, learn what kind of help each person prefers, get better at helping over time - like a helpful friend who knows when to help and when to let you figure things out.

all_rules.title: Explain AI Decisions Clearly
all_rules.content: Don't be a "black box" - show your reasoning, help people understand why you're making suggestions, be honest about uncertainty and limitations, build trust through transparency - like showing your math work instead of just the answer.

all_rules.title: Demonstrate Clear Value
all_rules.content: Show how the product saves time and money, make benefits obvious and measurable, connect features to real business outcomes, prove your worth every day - like showing how studying leads to better grades.

all_rules.title: Grow with the Customer
all_rules.content: Work well for small teams and huge organizations, adapt to different industries and needs, support both simple and complex situations, scale smoothly as needs grow - like clothes that can expand as you grow.

all_rules.title: Create "Magic Moments"
all_rules.content: Occasionally surprise and delight users, make some tasks feel effortless and magical, exceed expectations in small, meaningful ways, create features that people love to show others - like finding an extra french fry at the bottom of the bag.

all_rules.title: Remove Friction Everywhere
all_rules.content: Eliminate unnecessary steps and clicks, simplify complex processes, make common tasks fast and easy, smooth out rough edges in the experience - like making doors automatic so you don't have to push them.

all_rules.title: PR Template Block ‚Äî Code Review (paste into `.github/pull_request_template.md`)
PYTHON (FastAPI) QUALITY GATES
all_rules.content: - Tools: ruff + black (line length 100) + mypy --strict.

all_rules.title: TYPESCRIPT QUALITY GATES
all_rules.content: - tsconfig: "strict": true, "noImplicitAny": true, "exactOptionalPropertyTypes": true, ES2022+, ESNext modules.

all_rules.title: API CONTRACTS (HTTP)
all_rules.content: - OpenAPI 3.1 is the source of truth; URI versioning /v1, /v2...

all_rules.title: DATABASE (PostgreSQL primary; SQLite for dev/test)
all_rules.content: - SQLAlchemy 2.x; explicit columns (no SELECT *); name constraints/indexes.

all_rules.title: SECURITY & SECRETS
all_rules.content: - No secrets in code, tests, examples, logs, or repo. Use env + OS keyring/DPAPI. Provide .env.template only.

all_rules.title: OBSERVABILITY & RECEIPTS
all_rules.content: - Logs are structured JSON: timestamp, level, service, route, httpStatus, latencyMs, traceId/spanId, apiVersion.

all_rules.title: TESTING PROGRAM
all_rules.content: - Tests first; pytest (‚â•90% where applicable) + httpx for API; property tests with hypothesis where valuable.

all_rules.title: LLM / OLLAMA
all_rules.content: - Use pinned llama3 variant with deterministic params (low temperature, fixed seed); enforce token/time budgets.

all_rules.title: SUPPLY CHAIN & RELEASE INTEGRITY
all_rules.content: - Signed commits/tags; SBOMs attached; pinned lockfiles (pip-tools with hashes, npm ci).

all_rules.title: PERFORMANCE & RELIABILITY
all_rules.content: - Publish per-route SLOs (p95) in policy; add timeouts, retries (idempotent), backpressure; avoid event-loop blocking.

all_rules.title: DOCS & RUNBOOKS
all_rules.content: - Accurate OpenAPI; examples for all responses; ADRs for architectural changes; runbooks for migrations/rollbacks.

all_rules.title: RETURN CONTRACTS (OUTPUT FORMAT ‚Äî MUST PICK ONE)
all_rules.content: A) Unified Diff (default for code)

all_rules.title: STOP CONDITIONS ‚Üí ERROR CODES
all_rules.content: - Python/TS lint or format changes needed .................. ERROR:STYLE_VIOLATION

all_rules.title: WHERE COMMENTS MUST APPEAR
all_rules.content: A) File‚Äëlevel header (top of every file) ‚Äî in simple English:

all_rules.title: FILE‚ÄëTYPE FOCUS (add these in headers or near the write)
all_rules.content: - config: explain each setting; safe defaults; allowed range.

all_rules.title: SECURITY & PRIVACY
all_rules.content: - No secrets or PII in comments or examples. Use synthetic data only.

all_rules.title: RETURN CONTRACTS (OUTPUT FORMAT ‚Äî PICK ONE)
all_rules.content: A) Unified Diff (default for code)

all_rules.title: SELF‚ÄëAUDIT BEFORE OUTPUT
all_rules.content: - [ ] File header has What/Why/Reads‚ÄëWrites/Contracts/Risks

all_rules.title: STOP CONDITIONS ‚Üí ERROR CODES
all_rules.content: - Missing file header or public API docstring .......... ERROR:COMMENT_MISSING

all_rules.title: SOURCE OF TRUTH (PATHS YOU MAY TOUCH)
all_rules.content: - Contract SoT lives under:

all_rules.title: STYLE GUIDE (HTTP)
all_rules.content: - Verbs: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE (no RPC verbs).

all_rules.title: VERSIONING & COMPATIBILITY
all_rules.content: - URI versioning (/v1, /v2). Any breaking change REQUIRES a new major and deprecation of the old.

all_rules.title: SECURITY CONTRACTED IN SPEC
all_rules.content: - Auth schemes: JWT (aud, iss, exp, iat, kid) with documented scopes per route; (optional) mTLS.

all_rules.title: ERROR MODEL & MAPPING
all_rules.content: - Canonical codes defined in components/error‚Äëcodes.yaml (code, description, consumer action, retriable?, observability tag).

all_rules.title: CACHING & CONCURRENCY
all_rules.content: - ETag/If‚ÄëMatch required for racy PUT/PATCH; 412 on mismatch.

all_rules.title: TOOLING & CI GATES (AUTOMATE DISCIPLINE)
all_rules.content: - Spectral lint with custom rules (naming, security schemes, pagination, error envelope, examples-present) in `tools/contract-lint/.spectral.yaml` (required).

all_rules.title: RUNTIME ENFORCEMENT
all_rules.content: - FastAPI services: Pydantic v2 models; response_model on every route; central error handler returns the envelope.

all_rules.title: RECEIPTS & GOVERNANCE
all_rules.content: - Emit JSONL receipts for: contract.publish, contract.diff, contract.violation.

all_rules.title: METRICS & SLOs
all_rules.content: - Track: CI‚Äëblocked breaking attempts, time‚Äëto‚Äëdeprecate, coverage (% endpoints with examples/tests/SDKs), runtime conformance error rate, consumer contract failures.

all_rules.title: RETURN CONTRACTS (OUTPUT FORMAT ‚Äî PICK ONE)
all_rules.content: A) Unified Diff (default for contract edits)

all_rules.title: STOP CONDITIONS ‚Üí ERROR CODES
all_rules.content: - Spectral lint failure ................................. ERROR:OPENAPI_LINT_FAIL

all_rules.title: PATHS & WRITES (ROOTED FILE SYSTEM)
all_rules.content: - Resolve all paths via ZEROUI_ROOT + config/paths.json. Never hardcode drive letters or usernames.

all_rules.title: RECEIPTS, LOGGING & EVIDENCE
all_rules.content: - For any privileged action, append an INTENT receipt (JSONL) BEFORE writing code/data; then append a RESULT receipt after.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Keep apps stable, users calm, and debugging easy‚Äîby turning messy errors into a few clear, friendly outcomes.

all_rules.title: POLICY, SECRETS & PRIVACY
all_rules.content: - No hardcoded thresholds/messages. Read from policy snapshots/config. Enforce redaction for PII and secrets in examples, logs, receipts.

all_rules.title: API CONTRACTS (HTTP)
all_rules.content: - OpenAPI 3.1 as source of truth. URI versioning: /v1, /v2 ‚Ä¶ Breaking changes require a new major and deprecation of old.

all_rules.title: DATABASE (PostgreSQL primary; SQLite dev/test)
all_rules.content: - SQLAlchemy 2.x; explicit columns (no SELECT *); named constraints/indexes.

all_rules.title: PYTHON & TYPESCRIPT QUALITY GATES
all_rules.content: - Python: ruff + black (line-length 100) + mypy --strict; tests with pytest (‚â•90% where applicable).

all_rules.title: LLM / OLLAMA USAGE
all_rules.content: - Use pinned llama3 variant with deterministic params (low temperature, fixed seed). Enforce token/latency budgets.

all_rules.title: WINDOWS-FIRST & FILE HYGIENE
all_rules.content: - Respect EOL policy (.gitattributes): LF for code/config; CRLF for Windows scripts (.ps1, .iss, .wxs).

all_rules.title: TEST-FIRST & OBSERVABILITY
all_rules.content: - Add/adjust tests to cover the change. Include metrics/logs where relevant (latencyMs, route, httpStatus, apiVersion).

all_rules.title: RETURN CONTRACTS (OUTPUT FORMAT)
all_rules.content: - You MUST output exactly ONE of the following formats:

all_rules.title: STOP CONDITIONS ‚Üí ERROR CODES (MUST REFUSE)
all_rules.content: - Outside allowlist path‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ ERROR:OUTSIDE_ALLOWLIST

all_rules.title: SELF-AUDIT BEFORE OUTPUT (CHECKLIST)
all_rules.content: - [ ] ‚â§ 50 LOC (or LOC_OVERRIDE present)

all_rules.title: DEFINITION OF DONE (PER SUB-FEATURE PR)
all_rules.content: - Minimal diff; tests added/updated; receipts present

all_rules.title: LOG FORMAT & TRANSPORT
all_rules.content: - Format: ONE JSON object per line (JSONL).

all_rules.title: REQUIRED FIELDS (ALL LOGS)
all_rules.content: - log_schema_version: "1.0"

all_rules.title: FIELD CONSTRAINTS (TYPES & LIMITS)
all_rules.content: - event ‚â§ 40 chars; pattern: ^[a-z]+(\.[a-z_]+)*$

all_rules.title: HASHING POLICY (DETERMINISTIC)
all_rules.content: - SHA-256 over UTF-8 bytes.

all_rules.title: STABLE EVENT NAMES (MUST USE)
all_rules.content: - request.start / request.end (exactly one start and one end per handled request)

all_rules.title: LEVEL POLICY
all_rules.content: - Dev: default INFO; allow DEBUG for local.

all_rules.title: PRIVACY & PAYLOAD RULES
all_rules.content: - NEVER log secrets or raw PII. Redact tokens, passwords, keys, Authorization headers, cookies.

all_rules.title: CORRELATION & CONTEXT
all_rules.content: - Read/propagate W3C headers:

all_rules.title: RECEIPTS (AUDIT TRAIL)
all_rules.content: - For privileged or business-significant actions: emit a receipt (append-only JSONL) and log event "receipt.emit" with the receipt_id.

all_rules.title: PERFORMANCE BUDGETS & SAMPLING
all_rules.content: - Logging overhead should be < 5% CPU and < 2% latency on hot paths.

all_rules.title: PYTHON (FastAPI) & TYPESCRIPT RULES
all_rules.content: - Use a shared logger util that enforces schema and redaction. No print() or console.log() for runtime logs.

all_rules.title: STORAGE & RETENTION (LAPTOP-FIRST)
all_rules.content: - Path: <server>/logs/YYYY-MM-DD/*.jsonl (daily). Rotate at 100MB; keep last 10 files locally.

all_rules.title: STOP CONDITIONS ‚Üí ERROR CODES
all_rules.content: - Unstructured (not JSON) or multi-line log ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ ERROR:UNSTRUCTURED_LOG

all_rules.title: RETURN CONTRACTS (OUTPUT FORMAT ‚Äî PICK ONE)
all_rules.content: A) Unified Diff (default for code)

all_rules.title: SCHEMA VALIDATION (CI / PRE-COMMIT)
all_rules.content: - Validate events against docs/log_schema_v1.json (JSON Schema) in CI and pre-commit.

all_rules.title: Prevent First
all_rules.content: Validate inputs early (required, type, range, size). Prevention beats cure.

all_rules.title: Small, Stable Error Codes
all_rules.content: Adopt ~10‚Äì12 canonical codes with severity levels:

all_rules.title: Wrap & Chain
all_rules.content: When a low-level error occurs, wrap it into your code with a friendly message and keep the original as the cause. Never throw raw framework/driver errors at the edges.

all_rules.title: Central Handler at Boundaries
all_rules.content: Have one handler per surface (API endpoint, CLI entry, IDE command) that:

all_rules.title: Friendly to Users, Detailed in Logs
all_rules.content: Users see short, calm guidance. Logs contain context and the cause chain. Never leak secrets.

all_rules.title: No Silent Catches
all_rules.content: Never swallow errors. If you catch it, either fix, retry (if safe), or wrap & bubble to the central handler.

all_rules.title: Add Context
all_rules.content: Always include where/what (operation name, ids, step) when wrapping. This speeds up root-cause analysis.

all_rules.title: Cleanup Always
all_rules.content: Close files, sockets, timers; release locks. Use "always-run" cleanup paths. Avoid resource leaks.

all_rules.title: Error Recovery Patterns
all_rules.content: Define clear recovery actions for each error type:

all_rules.title: New Developer Onboarding
all_rules.content: - Provide "First Error Handling Task" template

all_rules.title: Timeouts Everywhere
all_rules.content: All I/O (network, file, DB, subprocess) must have a timeout (configurable). No infinite waits.

all_rules.title: Limited Retries with Backoff
all_rules.content: Retry only idempotent operations. Max 2‚Äì3 tries. Use exponential backoff + small jitter.

all_rules.title: Do Not Retry Non-Retriables
all_rules.content: No retries for validation errors, 401/403, 404, or business rule failures. Surface the issue; guide the user.

all_rules.title: Idempotency
all_rules.content: Design writes so they are safe to retry (keys/tokens/conflict handling). Document this in your service contract.

all_rules.title: (Reserved)
all_rules.content: See

all_rules.title: HTTP/Exit Mapping
all_rules.content: Map canonical codes to standard outcomes (e.g., 400/401/403/404/409/422/429/5xx). No "200 with error body".

all_rules.title: Message Catalog
all_rules.content: Keep a single catalog that maps each code ‚Üí one friendly, human sentence. Translate here, not in code.

all_rules.title: UI/IDE Behavior
all_rules.content: Keep UI responsive. Show short, actionable options: Retry / Cancel / Open Logs. No stack traces to users.

all_rules.title: Structured Logs
all_rules.content: One JSON object per line. Include: timestamp, level, service, operation, error.code, trace/request ids, duration, attempt, retryable flag, severity, and a cause chain summary.

all_rules.title: Correlation
all_rules.content: Propagate trace/request ids across calls. Log exactly one request.start and one request.end per request.

all_rules.title: Privacy & Secrets
all_rules.content: Never log secrets or PII. Redact tokens, passwords, cookies, Authorization headers, and sensitive payloads. Log sizes/hashes, not raw bodies.

all_rules.title: Test Failure Paths
all_rules.content: Write tests for:

all_rules.title: Contracts & Docs
all_rules.content: Document the error envelope, code list, HTTP mapping, and examples. Keep examples up to date and non-PII.

all_rules.title: Consistency Over Cleverness
all_rules.content: Prefer consistent handling over one-off fixes. If a new case appears, map it to an existing code first.

all_rules.title: Safe Defaults
all_rules.content: Default timeouts, retry caps, and user messages must be safe and configurable. No hidden magic numbers.

all_rules.title: AI Decision Transparency
all_rules.content: When AI suggests something, include:

all_rules.title: AI Sandbox Safety
all_rules.content: AI should only work in a special "playground" (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

all_rules.title: AI Learning from Mistakes
all_rules.content: When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like learning from test questions.

all_rules.title: AI Confidence Thresholds
all_rules.content: - High confidence (>90%): Apply automatically with user notification

all_rules.title: Graceful Degradation
all_rules.content: When dependencies fail, provide reduced functionality rather than complete failure. Show clear status of what's working vs. limited.

all_rules.title: State Recovery
all_rules.content: After crashes or failures, systems should recover to known good states. Maintain recovery checkpoints for long-running operations.

all_rules.title: Feature Flag Safety
all_rules.content: Use feature flags for risky changes with automatic rollback on error detection. Monitor error rates by flag state.

all_rules.title: Strict Mode Always
all_rules.content: Turn on strict checks everywhere. (Meaning: the compiler catches more mistakes early.)

all_rules.title: No `any` in committed code
all_rules.content: If you don't know the type, use

all_rules.title: Handle `null`/`undefined`
all_rules.content: Use optional fields only when needed, and

all_rules.title: Small, Clear Functions
all_rules.content: Short functions, clear names. One job per function.

all_rules.title: Clear Shape Strategy
all_rules.content: Use

all_rules.title: Let the Compiler Infer
all_rules.content: Don't add types the compiler already knows. (Meaning: avoid noisy annotations.)

all_rules.title: Keep Imports Clean
all_rules.content: No unused imports. Group by built-in, third-party, then local.

all_rules.title: Describe the Shape
all_rules.content: Make simple named types for real data (User, Order). Reuse them.

all_rules.title: Union & Narrowing
all_rules.content: If something can be

all_rules.title: Readonly by Default
all_rules.content: Prefer readonly arrays/props for values that should not change.

all_rules.title: Discriminated Unions
all_rules.content: When you have variants, add a simple

all_rules.title: Utility Types, Not Duplicates
all_rules.content: Use `Partial`, `Pick`, `Omit`, `Record` to avoid copy-pasting shapes.

all_rules.title: Generics, But Simple
all_rules.content: Use generics when it truly makes code reusable. Keep names short and clear.

all_rules.title: No Unhandled Promises
all_rules.content: Always `await` or handle `.catch`. Never let a promise fail silently.

all_rules.title: Timeouts & Cancel
all_rules.content: Use timeouts for network/work that may hang. Support

all_rules.title: Friendly Errors at Edges
all_rules.content: Catch errors at boundaries (commands, routes) and show

all_rules.title: Map Errors to Codes
all_rules.content: Convert messy errors into a

all_rules.title: Retries Are Limited
all_rules.content: Retry only

all_rules.title: One Source of Truth
all_rules.content: Keep types for APIs in one place (e.g., generated from contracts). Don't hand-roll duplicates.

all_rules.title: Folder Layout
all_rules.content: Group by

all_rules.title: Paths & Aliases
all_rules.content: Use path aliases in config (short imports), but

all_rules.title: Modern Output Targets
all_rules.content: Target modern JS (ES2022+) for optimal tree-shaking. Keep configs in repo. Builds must be reproducible.

all_rules.title: Lint & Format
all_rules.content: Use eslint + prettier. No warnings in CI.

all_rules.title: Type Check in CI
all_rules.content: Run the compiler (`tsc`) with strict settings on every PR.

all_rules.title: Tests for New Behavior
all_rules.content: Add tests for new logic and for error paths (timeouts, bad input). Keep tests fast.

all_rules.title: Comments in Simple English
all_rules.content: Explain

all_rules.title: No Secrets in Code or Logs
all_rules.content: Never commit tokens/passwords. Redact sensitive values from logs.

all_rules.title: Validate Untrusted Inputs at Runtime
all_rules.content: Types help at build time only. Validate external data before use.

all_rules.title: Keep the UI Responsive
all_rules.content: Do heavy work off the main thread. Show progress for long tasks.

all_rules.title: Review AI Code Thoroughly
all_rules.content: All AI-generated TypeScript must be reviewed by humans. Verify types, error handling, and security match our standards.

all_rules.title: Monitor Bundle Impact
all_rules.content: Use path imports for large libraries. Avoid barrel imports in hot paths. Set bundle size budgets and monitor them.

all_rules.title: Quality Dependencies
all_rules.content: Prefer packages with built-in TypeScript definitions. Use `@types/` packages from DefinitelyTyped. Audit dependencies for type safety.

all_rules.title: Test Type Boundaries
all_rules.content: Write tests that verify type narrowing works. Test error cases to ensure proper typing. Use `@ts-expect-error` for expected type failures.

all_rules.title: Gradual Migration Strategy
all_rules.content: When converting JavaScript to TypeScript, use `// @ts-check` in JS files first. Add JSDoc types before conversion. Convert one module at a time.

all_rules.title: Name Casing & Charset (Kebab-Case Only)
all_rules.content: All folder names must use kebab-case: only lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens [a-z0-9-]. No uppercase, no underscores, no spaces. This ensures consistency and avoids path resolution issues across platforms.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: No Source Code/PII in Stores
all_rules.content: Storage must never contain source code or personally identifiable information (PII). Use handles, IDs, and metadata only. Receipts and evidence stores are for facts about work, not the work itself.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: No Secrets/Private Keys on Disk
all_rules.content: Never store secrets, passwords, API keys, or private keys on disk. Use secrets manager, HSM, or KMS. Only public keys may be stored in `trust/pubkeys/`. Load sensitive configuration from environment variables or secure vaults.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: JSONL Receipts (Newline-Delimited, Signed, Append-Only)
all_rules.content: Receipts are the legal truth. Format: newline-delimited JSON (JSONL), one record per line. Each line must be signed over canonical JSON. Receipts are append-only‚Äînever modify or delete existing entries. Invalid lines go to quarantine (laptop) or DLQ (cloud).
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: Time Partitions Use UTC (dt=YYYY-MM-DD)
all_rules.content: All time-based partitions must use UTC format: `dt=YYYY-MM-DD` (zero-padded). Example: `dt=2025-10-20`. Never use local time, YYYYMMDD format, or MM-DD-YYYY. Optional hot sharding: `dt=.../shard={00..ff}/`.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: Policy Snapshots Must Be Signed
all_rules.content: All policy snapshots and templates must be signed. Laptops cache policies; authoritative publishing happens in the Product plane. Policy files are JSON and signed for integrity verification.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: Dual Storage Compliance (JSONL Authority, DB Mirrors)
all_rules.content: JSONL is the authority. Databases (SQLite/Postgres) mirror data for read/query performance, storing raw JSON verbatim with minimal indexes. The database is a read/index plane only. Always write to JSONL first, then mirror to DB.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: Path Resolution via ZU_ROOT Environment Variable
all_rules.content: All storage paths must be resolved via `ZU_ROOT` environment variable or `config/paths.json`. Never hardcode absolute paths like `D:\ZeroUI` or `/home/user/zeroui`. Enables portable, configurable deployments.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: Receipts Validation (Signed, Append-Only, No Code/PII)
all_rules.content: When reading receipts, always verify signatures. Receipts must never contain source code or PII‚Äîonly handles, IDs, and metadata. Enforce append-only semantics: use file mode "a", never "w"; never truncate or seek.
all_rules.section: üéØ **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

all_rules.title: Evidence Watermarks Per-Consumer Structure
all_rules.content: Evidence watermarks must follow per-consumer structure: `.../evidence/watermarks/{consumer-id}/`. Each consumer (metrics, traces, logs, etc.) has its own watermark directory for tracking processing progress.

all_rules.title: RFC Fallback Pattern (UNCLASSIFIED__slug, 24h Resolution)
all_rules.content: When data classification is ambiguous, use RFC fallback: `UNCLASSIFIED__<slug>` (kebab-case slug). Place in:

all_rules.title: Observability/Adapters Use dt= Partitions
all_rules.content: Observability and adapter paths require date partitions (`dt=YYYY-MM-DD`):

all_rules.title: Laptop Receipts Use YYYY/MM Partitioning
all_rules.content: Laptop (IDE) receipts use month partitioning: `ide/agent/receipts/{repo-id}/{YYYY}/{MM}/`. Example: `ide/agent/receipts/zeroui2-0/2025/10/`. Auxiliary folders (index, quarantine, checkpoints) live under the same repo path.

all_rules.content: Receipts are newline-delimited JSON (JSONL), append-only. Never rewrite. Each receipt is signed; reject or quarantine any receipt missing a signature.

all_rules.content: If `rollout.cohorts` or `rollout.ladder` are present, enforce exactly as declared. If absent, use `rollout.default_mode`. Never assume implied cohorts.

all_rules.content: Where `tests.fixtures[]` are present, unit/integration tests MUST prove the declared outcomes (`pass | warn | soft_block | hard_block`). Do not merge if observed outcomes differ from fixtures.

all_rules.title: Runtime Snapshot Binding
all_rules.content: At decision time, the engine MUST bind to the exact snapshot referenced by the receipt (`policy_version_ids[]` and `policy_snapshot_hash`). Never apply a different snapshot than the one recorded.

all_rules.title: Plain English Variable Names
all_rules.content: Use descriptive, everyday words instead of technical jargon or abbreviations.

all_rules.title: Self-Documenting Code
all_rules.content: Code should read like a story, not a puzzle.

all_rules.title: One Concept Per Function
all_rules.content: Each function should do exactly one thing.

all_rules.title: Explain the "Why", Not Just the "What"
all_rules.content: Comments should explain business logic, not code mechanics.

all_rules.title: Avoid Mental Gymnastics
all_rules.content: No nested ternary operators, complex one-liners, or clever tricks.

all_rules.title: Use Real-World Analogies
all_rules.content: Compare technical concepts to everyday experiences.

all_rules.title: Progressive Complexity
all_rules.content: Start simple, add complexity only when needed.

all_rules.title: Visual Code Layout
all_rules.content: Use whitespace to group related ideas.

all_rules.title: Error Messages That Help
all_rules.content: Error messages should guide users to solutions.

all_rules.title: Consistent Naming Patterns
all_rules.content: Use the same word for the same concept throughout.

all_rules.title: Avoid Abbreviations
all_rules.content: Write out full words unless universally understood.

all_rules.title: Business Language Over Technical Language
all_rules.content: Use domain terms that business people understand.

all_rules.title: Show Your Work
all_rules.content: Break complex calculations into steps with intermediate variables.

all_rules.title: Fail Gracefully with Helpful Messages
all_rules.content: When something goes wrong, explain what the user should do.

all_rules.title: Code as Documentation
all_rules.content: The code itself should be the primary documentation.

all_rules.title: Test Names That Tell a Story
all_rules.content: Test names should describe the scenario and expected outcome.

all_rules.title: Constants That Explain Themselves
all_rules.content: Use named constants instead of magic numbers.
